abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Irrigation
            Systems Rehabilitation Project for Pakistan was
            satisfactory. The project achieved some of its objectives,
            its impact on institutional development was partially
            successful, sustainability is uncertain at this time, and
            both the Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, sustaining
            Pakistan's irrigation systems requires developing
            beneficiary-oriented, autonomous, commercially-oriented
            public utilities in tandem with more positive participatory
            management by beneficiaries. Second, delay in project
            start-up (15 months from board to effectiveness) was due to
            delay in ECNEC and USAID approval. Both the Government and
            co-financier should have expedited the procedure to avoid
            delays. Third, it is impossible to estimate the benefits of
            irrigation and drainage development without carrying out
            agro-economic monitoring and evaluation. Finally, there
            still remains much to be improved in the technical ability
            of small contractors.
